entry.title: Bitcoin Forking Guide
entry.summary:
The document outlines a project focused on exploring advanced user functionalities within a specific domain, as highlighted by the work shared at [delvingbitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/ln-symmetry-project-recap/359). This exploration aims to achieve three primary goals, emphasizing the potential for applying the outcomes to validate various proposals such as CTV+CSFS / TXHASH+CSFS. However, it acknowledges that any adaptation of this work to support new proposals would require significant effort from those advocating for these changes.
The discussion raises an important consideration regarding the focus on protocol development within projects. It suggests that an overly rigid concentration on protocols might not be beneficial, given the evolving nature of project requirements and the shifting landscape of Layer 2 (L2) architectures. The text implies that the relevance of research findings to practical applications, particularly in the context of L2 solutions, serves as an indicator of the alignment between theoretical proposals and their utility in real-world scenarios. This observation points to a possible misalignment between current research outputs and their applicability, underlining the need for a more adaptable approach.
Moreover, the narrative touches upon the concept of composability as a critical factor in the development process, suggesting that it should be prioritized even if it comes at the cost of increased byte usage within transactions. This perspective advocates for a balance between enhancing functionality and managing the technical overhead, hinting at the complex trade-offs involved in optimizing protocol design for broader, more versatile applications.
